questions.text: A patient complains of eye pain and difficulty seeing after watching a movie. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mannitol with pilocarpine:

  • The scenario describes a patient presenting with symptoms after watching a movie, which is suggestive of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APACG). Mannitol helps to reduce intraocular pressure rapidly, and pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and pulls the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, thereby opening the drainage angle.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and D: Moxifloxacin and carboxymethylcellulose have no effect on intraocular pressure.

Option C: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which can worsen angle closure by increasing the pupillary block.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for the child in the image who displays enlarged corneas, sensitivity to light, and excessive tearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • The symptoms of large corneas, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing) in the child in the picture are indicative of congenital glaucoma. Congenital glaucoma refers to a form of glaucoma that is present at birth or develops within the first few years of life. It is typically caused by abnormalities in the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B) Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a rare childhood eye cancer that affects the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. While retinoblastoma can present with various symptoms, such as leukocoria (white pupil), strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), and decreased vision, the specific symptoms mentioned in the question, such as large corneas and lacrimation, are not typical manifestations of retinoblastoma.

Option C) Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cornea, specifically the endothelial cells responsible for maintaining corneal transparency. Symptoms of CHED usually include cloudy or hazy corneas, decreased vision, and sometimes nystagmus (involuntary eye movements). While the child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation, these symptoms are more suggestive of congenital glaucoma rather than CHED.

Option D) Megalocornea: Megalocornea is a condition characterized by abnormally large corneas. It is often inherited and can be associated with other ocular abnormalities. While megalocornea can be asymptomatic or associated with mild visual disturbances, the presence of photophobia and lacrimation in the child suggests a more likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma, which is specifically associated with increased intraocular pressure and related symptoms.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old woman who is experiencing sudden eye pain and redness? An image of her eye is provided for reference.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute angle-closure glaucoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female presenting with an acute painful red-eye and an image showing redness and congestion which gives a diagnosis of Acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma:

  • Acute angle-closure glaucoma is a sudden and severe form of glaucoma characterized by a rapid increase in intraocular pressure. It occurs when the drainage angle of the eye becomes blocked, leading to a buildup of fluid and pressure within the eye.

Clinical features of Glaucoma are:

  1. Sudden Painful eye.

  2. A ciliary flush around the cornea due to dilated ciliary veins, and in long-standing cases, caput medusae with prominent vessels.

  3. Cornea - initially clear but insensitive, later becoming hazy, with epithelial bullae (bullous keratopathy) or filaments (filamentary keratitis).

  4. Headache and nausea: Some individuals may experience accompanying headache, nausea, and even vomiting.

  5. Anterior chamber - very shallow.

  6. Iris - atrophic.

  7. Pupil - fixed and dilated.

  8. Optic disc - glaucomatous optic atrophy.

  9. IOP is high and the eyeball becomes stony hard.

Management of absolute glaucoma

In absolute glaucoma, the goal of treatment is to relieve pain and reduce IOP, as vision cannot be restored.

  • Retrobulbar alcohol injection - given to relieve pain. First, 1 mL of 2% xylocaine is injected followed after about 5-10 minutes by 1 mL of 80% alcohol. It suppresses the ciliary ganglion.

  • A cyclodestructive procedure, such as cyclocryotherapy or cyclophotocoagulation, is the most appropriate management option in this scenario as it reduces aqueous production by damaging the secretory ciliary processes aiming to reduce IOP.

  • If pain persists despite cyclodestruction, enucleation/evisceration may be considered.

Incorrect Options

Acute retrobulbar neuritis (Option A), also known as optic neuritis, typically presents with vision loss, eye pain, and decreased color vision. It is not characterized by redness and congestion of the eye, so it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

Acute anterior uveitis (Option C), also known as iritis, is inflammation of the iris and the anterior chamber of the eye. It commonly presents with symptoms of a red, painful eye with photophobia (sensitivity to light) and decreased vision. The image showing redness and congestion supports this diagnosis. Acute anterior uveitis can be associated with underlying systemic conditions such as ankylosing spondylitis or reactive arthritis. It is the most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario.

Severe keratoconjunctivitis (Option D) refers to inflammation of both the cornea and the conjunctiva. While it can cause redness and irritation of the eye, it is not commonly associated with acute onset and severe pain. It is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: The drug increasing uveoscleral flow is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Latanoprost

Explanation:

Medical management of glaucoma

1. Medical:

The drugs either decrease the formation of aqueous or increase the drainage to decrease IOP. This is of 2 types:

  1. Topical (6 types)
  2. Systemic (2 types)

Topical:

  • Beta-blockers
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: Timolol (Option A) , betaxolol
    • C/I in asthma
    • S/E: corneal anesthesia and blepharoconjunctivitis
  • Alpha agonists:
    • They have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
    • Brimonidine is safe in pregnancy
    • Adrenaline is C/I in aphakic glaucoma
  • Miotics:
    • These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage
    • Eg: Pilocarpine (Option C)
    • S/E of Pilocarpine: Pseudo myopia, retinal detachment, shallow anterior chamber, iris cysts
  • Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors:
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: dorzolamide and brinzolamide
    • These are C/I in sulpha allergies
  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: this increases the contractile property of the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing the trabecular outflow and it also decreases the aqueous production.
    • It is a Rho-kinase inhibitor
    • S/E: vortex keratopathy
  • PGF2 alpha agonist:
    • It increases the uveoscleral outflow
    • These are also contraindicated in uveitis and asthma
    • For eg- Latanoprost (Option B), bimatoprost, travoprost , tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl
    • Latanoprost causes heterochromia iridis
    • Bimatoprost increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow
    • Side effects: Hypertrichosis

Systemic:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • For eg: acetazolamide(Option D), methazolamide
    • S/E: Tingling and numbness, constipation, renal stones, and a bad metallic taste
  • Hyperosmotic agents:
    • These draw aqueous out of the eye
    • For eg: I/V mannitol (C/I in heart disease), glycerol (C/I in diabetes), isosorbide, and urea

questions.text:
True regarding POAG:


	Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy
	First degree relatives have more chances of developing steroid induced glaucoma
	Dilatation of pupil is associated with exacerbation of IOP
	First degree relatives are at 1% increased risk of POAG
	Visual field defect can exist with normal C:D ratio
questions.solution:
Correct option: C) 2 and 5 only

Explanation:

Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG)

Characteristics:

  • Intraocular Pressure: Elevated (>21 mm Hg) on multiple occasions.
  • Anterior Chamber Angle: Open and normal in appearance (Statement 3).
  • Optic Disc: Characteristic cupping , normal C:D ratio in early stages (Statement 5).
  • Visual Field: Specific defects present.

Risk Factors:

  • Elevated IOP: Asymmetry of IOP of ≥4 mmHg is considered significant. (Option A)
  • Family History: Higher risk in siblings (10%) (Statement 4) and offspring (4%). Involves polygenic inheritance with genes like MYOC, OPTN, and WDR36. (Option C)
  • Age: Increased risk with age, especially between the 5th and 7th decades of life.
  • Race: Higher prevalence and severity in Black individuals compared to Whites.
  • Myopia: Increased risk in myopic individuals. (Option D)
  • Thinner Central Corneal Thickness (CCT) (<555 µm) is an independent risk factor.
  • Cigarette Smoking: Increased risk
  • Blood Pressure: Higher prevalence in hypertensives; diastolic perfusion pressure <55 mm Hg is a significant risk factor. (Option B)
  • Thyrotoxicosis: Increased in Graves' ophthalmic disease.
  • Corticosteroid Responsiveness: Greater risk of IOP rise with topical steroid therapy (Statement 2).

Pathogenesis:

  • The rise in IOP in POAG occurs due to decreased aqueous outflow facility. This is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening and apposition of Schlemm's canal wall.
  • Contributing factors include thickening and sclerosis of the trabecular meshwork, narrowing of intertrabecular spaces, deposition of amorphous material in the juxtacanalicular space, and collapse of Schlemm's canal.

Abnormality of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy (Statement 1) although trabecular meshwork is seen in gonioscopy, abnormalities in the trabecular meshwork cannot be observed during gonioscopy.

questions.text: In a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma, which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Marcus Gunn pupil

Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD):

  • The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception.
  • This is also called the Marcus Gunn Pupil (Option A) (first sign of optic nerve disorder).
  • Causes:
  • Optic neuritis
  • Optic neuropathy
  • Chiasmal compression
  • Intraocular hemorrhage
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Retinal detachment
  • Optic tract lesion
  • Central or branch arterial occlusion
  • Central or branch vein occlusion
  • Anisometropic amblyopia
  • Cataract
  • Corneal scar
  • Visual pathway damage
  • Tested by Swinging Flashlight Test .
    • A bright flashlight is shone onto one pupil, causing constriction, then quickly moved to the opposite pupil to observe its response. This process is repeated multiple times to assess the pupillary reactions.
    • Normally, both pupils constrict equally, but the pupil to which light is transferred remains tightly constricted.
    • In RAPD, the affected pupil dilates when the flashlight moves from the normal to the abnormal eye.
    • The dilatation that occurs is commonly called the Marcus Gunn pupil or RAPD (Relative afferent pupillary defect).

 

Adie’s Pupil (Option B) shows no reaction to light, and the near reflex is very slow and tonic. It shows pupillary constriction to 0.125% Pilocarpine due to denervation supersensitivity. Seen in Postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP) (Option C) shows reaction to near reflex, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e. there is light near dissociation. Seen in Neurosyphilis

Hutchinson’s pupil (Option D) This refers to a fixed, dilated pupil due to a midbrain lesion or uncal herniation. It is not typically seen in glaucoma.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old infant who was brought in by their mother due to complaints of light sensitivity, difficulty opening the eyes, and excessive tearing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma:

  • The presence of classic triad of symptoms- watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm in a 2-month old infant are all consistent with Congenital glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma:

Types
  1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

questions.text: Which medication should be avoided in a 30-year-old female presenting with redness, pain, increased intraocular pressure, keratic precipitates, and aqueous flare?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prostaglandin analogues

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of redness, pain, keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and increased intraocular pressure is suggestive of anterior uveitis induced glaucoma. Prostaglandin analogues are contraindicated in cases of Uveitis as it may aggravate the inflammation.

 

Anti-Glaucoma drugs:

Prostaglandin Analogues:

Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost

Mechanism:

Increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis

Contraindications:

Cystoid macular edema, diabetes mellitus, Anterior Uveitis (Option D)

Beta Blockers: (Option A)

  • Non-Selective: Timolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol
  • Selective: Betaxolol, Levobetaxolol

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia

Alpha-2 Agonists:

Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes)

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

Contraindications:

Children <2 years

Additional:

Brimonidine: Safest during pregnancy (Category B)

Miotics:

Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate

Mechanism:

Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow

Adverse effects:

Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors: (Option C)

Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical)

Mechanism:

Inhibits aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma

Osmotic agents: (Option B)

Mannitol (IV), Glycerol (oral)

Mechanism:

Lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient

Adverse effects:

Cardiac overload, urinary retention

 

Newer Drugs:

  • Netarsudil (Rho kinase inhibitor): Increases trabecular outflow; Side effect - vortex keratopathy
  • Omidenepag (PGE2 agonist): Increases both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow

questions.text: Which of the following medications should not be administered to a patient with a known case of angle closure glaucoma who has also been diagnosed with major depressive disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amitriptyline

 

Explanation:

Amitriptyline, a Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) should not be administered to a known case of Angle closure glaucoma due to its antagonistic action on M1 (Muscarinic) receptor.

 

Amitriptyline:

  • MOA: Primarily blocks Serotonin (5HT3) and Norepinephrine (NE) reuptake; also has additional blocking action on ɑ1 (adrenergic), H1 (Histamine) and M1 (Muscarinic) receptors.
  • ADRs: Orthostatic hypotension, GI disturbances, seizures, increases risk of suicidal thoughts, sexual dysfunction.
  • Contraindication: Angle closure glaucoma

 

Common drugs contraindicated in Angle closure glaucoma patients:

Anti-Muscarinic
  • Ipratropium bromide, Thiotropium bromide (M1)
  • Toletrodine, Oxybutinin (M3)
  • Scopolamine (M1)

Anti-Histaminics
  • Diphenhydramine, Fexofenadine (H1)
  • Cimetidine, Ranitidine (H2)

Migraine drugs
  • Sumatriptan

Anti-depressants
  • SNRI: Duloxetine and Milnacipram
  • TCA: Amitryptiline

Anti-Epileptics
  • Topiramate, Zonisamide

Antibiotics
  • Trimethoprim-Sulfametoxazole (Cotrimoxazole)

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Goldmann applanation tonometer

Explanation:

The gold standard instrument for measuring intraocular pressure is Goldmann applanation tonometer.

Applanation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A).
  • Goldmann Applanation Tonometer: (Option B)
    • Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp.
    • Technique:
      • Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein.
      • Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light.
      • The prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch.
      • IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten.

[1]

 

Variable force tonometers:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard
  • Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann)
    • Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP)
    • Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins
    • It has a different set of prisms
    • It operates with a motor
  • Pulsair (non-contact tonometer)
  • Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation) (Option D)
  • Rebound tonometer

Fixed force tonometers:

  • Maklakov tonometer
  • Barraquer tonometer

Gonioscope (Option A): Gonioscope is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber.

Hertel’s exophthalmometer (Option C): Hertel’s exophthalmometer is used to measure the protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a neonate who presents with symptoms of photophobia and excessive tearing, along with a clinical examination showing a normal tear passage and a clear, but abnormally large cornea, and the presence of Haab's striae in the eye image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Buphthalmos

Explanation:

The presence of classic symptoms- watering, photophobia with abnormally large cornea in a neonate are all consistent with Buphthalmos- Congenital glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma:

Types
  • Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  • Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  • Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

 

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

 

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

Keratoconus (Option B): is frequently due to congenital weakness of cornea, though it manifests only after puberty. In keratoconus, the cornea thins near the center and progressively bulges forwards, with the apex of the cone always being slightly below the center of the cornea. Important signs include: Munson sign (acute bulge given to the lower lid when the patient looks down), acute hydrops (due to ruptures in the Descemet’s membrane), Vogt striae and Fleischer ring may be seen in the later stages.

Trachoma (Option C): is the chronic inflammatory disease affecting primarily the conjunctiva, but later secondarily affecting the lids and the cornea. The organism responsible is Chlamydia trachomatis. From the clinical point of view, the diagnostic features of trachoma depend on the following characteristics: Follicles in the upper palpebral conjunctiva (Sago-grain appearance), pannus, limbal follicles or their sequelae as Herbert pits, in later stages, typical stellate trachomatous scarring in the conjunctiva.

Keratoglobus (Option D): is a congenital anomaly in which there is hemispherical protrusion of the whole cornea, occurring bilaterally. It is familial and hereditary. It differs from buphthalmos in that the intraocular pressure is normal, cornea is clear, refractive errors are with-the-rule astigmatism, angle of the anterior chamber normal and there is no cupping of the optical disc.

questions.text: After an acute episode of angle-closure glaucoma, which triad of symptoms is typically observed?
questions.solution:
• Vogt's triad is a clinical set of findings typically associated with acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) after an attack has been resolved.
  • The triad helps in identifying damage caused during the acute episode.

 

Features of APAC:

  • Descemet membrane folds
  • Iris atrophy
  • Irregular pupil
  • Glaucomflecken
  • Cataract
  • Cupping +/-

 

Vogt’s triad:

It may be seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute PAC. It is characterized by:

  1. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil (due to sphincter atrophy)
  2. Glaucomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity)
  3. Patches of iris atrophy

Virchow's triad (Option B): This refers to the three factors that predispose to thrombosis: stasis of blood flow, vascular injury, and hypercoagulability. It is used in the context of venous thrombosis, not glaucoma.

 

Hutchinson's triad (Option C): This refers to a set of findings associated with congenital syphilis, including notched incisors, interstitial keratitis, and sensorineural hearing loss.


Gaucher's triad (Option D): This refers to symptoms seen in Gaucher's disease, a genetic disorder involving lipid storage. The triad includes hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and anemia, unrelated to glaucoma.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is atropine not recommended for use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option A)

Explanation

  • Atropine is not recommended for use in acute congestive glaucoma.
  • This is because atropine is an anticholinergic that causes pupil dilation, which can exacerbate the already elevated intraocular pressure in acute congestive (or angle-closure) glaucoma by further obstructing the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. This can worsen the condition.
  • Over 60 drugs have been linked to acute angle-closure (AAC) glaucoma, particularly in individuals with ocular predispositions. These include topical anticholinergic pupil dilators (e.g., atropine, cyclopentolate) and systemic medications such as topiramate, sulfonamides, duloxetine, and phenothiazines. Patients on these medications, especially those with AAC risk factors, should have regular ophthalmic examinations.

 

Acute anterior uveitis (Option B): Atropine can be beneficial in this condition as it helps to relieve ciliary muscle spasms, reduces pain, prevents the formation of posterior synechiae, and keeps the pupil mobile.

 

Malignant glaucoma (Option C): Atropine is the first line of treatment for management of malignant glaucoma. It dilates the ciliary ring and relaxes the ciliary muscles which causes stretching of zonules that will pull back the lens, thus opening the block.

 

Corneal ulcer (Option D): Atropine can be used in this case to help relieve pain associated with ciliary muscle spasms, reduces pain, prevents the formation of posterior synechiae, and improve vascularity.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an infant brought in with symptoms of excessive tear production, sensitivity to light, and blepharospasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital glaucoma

Explanation:

  • True Congenital Glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth.
  • The presence of Haab’s striae, early onset, enlarged corneas, and the classic triad of symptoms (watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm) are all consistent with newborn glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma

Types

1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. (40% cases)

Typically presents within the first month of life.

Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions.

2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age- Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday

Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years.

Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations.

3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age.

Buphthalmos, meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP.
  • Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum.
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features

Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.

Corneal Signs:

  • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
  • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.

Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.

Additional Features:

  • Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
  • Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages.
  • Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
  • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
  • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Incorrect Options:

Congenital Cataract (Option B): Causes a cloudy lens and poor vision, but doesn’t typically cause excessive tearing, light sensitivity, or blepharospasm.

Congenital Dacryocystitis (Option C): Leads to tearing and discharge from a blocked tear duct but doesn’t cause light sensitivity or blepharospasm.

Ophthalmia Neonatorum (Option D): Involves eye redness and discharge due to infection at birth, but doesn’t cause light sensitivity or spasms.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden painful decrease in vision and a fixed, vertically oval pupil. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute congestive glaucoma

Explanation:

  • Acute congestive glaucoma is characterized by sudden painful decrease in vision and fixed vertically oval pupil
  • Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) after an attack has been resolved.
  • The triad helps in identifying damage caused during the acute episode.

Features of APAC:

  • Descemet membrane folds
  • Iris atrophy
  • Irregular pupil (Option C)
  • Glaucomflecken
  • Cataract
  • Cupping +/-

Vogt’s triad:

It may be seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute PAC. It is characterized by:

  1. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil (due to sphincter atrophy)
  2. Glaucomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity)
  3. Patches of iris atrophy

 

Incorrect Options:

Macular degeneration (Option A):

  • It is characterized by irreversible loss of vision
  • Fixed oval pupils is not a feature of this condition

Optic neuritis (Option B) are normal in Optic neuritis
Acute anterior uveitis (Option D) is characterized by a dilated, festooned-shaped pupil

questions.text: A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the Right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the Left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phacolytic glaucoma:

  • Flare cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, cataractous lens, and unequal IOP point towards the diagnosis of phacolytic glaucoma.
  • It is a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma in which trabecular meshwork is clogged by the lens proteins, macrophages which have phagocytosed the lens proteins, and inflammatory debris.
  • Leakage of the lens proteins occurs through an intact capsule in the hypermature (Morgagnian) cataractous lens.
  • The anterior chamber may become deep, and the aqueous may contain fine white protein particles, which settle down as pseudohypopyon.
  • Anterior chamber angle is open on gonioscopy, and aqueous flare or cells may be seen in the anterior chamber.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Malignant glaucoma:

  • In Malignant glaucoma, shallowing of the anterior chamber is noticed and Seidel’s test is negative.

Option C - Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis:

  • In Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis, low-grade flare and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments may be seen but IOP is not very high as in the above case.

Option D - Phacomorphic glaucoma:

  • In Phacomorphic glaucoma, ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and intumescent senile cataractous lens is noted.

questions.text: What is the gold standard method for measuring intraocular pressure in patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Goldmann applanation tonometer

Explanation:

Types of Tonometry:

1. Indentation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP by how much a plunger indents the eye; softer eyes indent more than harder eyes.
  • Schiotz Tonometer:
    • Most widely used tonometer in the world.
    • Advantages: Inexpensive, simple, and reliable.
    • Disadvantages: Gives false readings in eyes with abnormal scleral rigidity (e.g., high myopes, post-surgery).

2. Applanation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A).
  • Goldmann Tonometer (Option B):
    • Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp.
    • Technique:
      • Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein.
      • Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light.
      • The prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch.
      • IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten.

Variable force tonometers:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard
  • Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann)
  • Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP)
    • Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins
    • It has a different set of prisms
    • It operates with a motor
  • Pulsair (non-contact tonometer)
  • Airpuff (non-contact tonometer)
  • Grolman (non-contact tonometer)
  • Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation) (Option D)
  • MacKay Marg (based on both indentation and applanation)
  • Rebound tonometer
  • Transpalpebral Tonometer

Fixed force tonometer:

  1. Maklakov tonometer
  2. Barraquer tonometer

Hertel’s exophthalmometer (Option A) is used to measure the degree of exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyeball) in conditions such as thyroid eye disease.

Gonioscope (Option B) is a specialized lens used to visualize the iridocorneal angle, which is important in assessing angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: The first line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PG analogues

Explanation:

Treatment of glaucoma:

  • There are 3 types of treatment modalities:
    • Medical management
    • Laser
    • Surgery

1. Medical:

The drugs either decrease the formation of aqueous or increase the drainage to decrease IOP. This is of 2 types:

  • Topical (6 types)
  • Systemic (2 types)

Topical:

PGF2 alpha agonist:

  • It increases the uveoscleral outflow
  • First line in glaucoma
  • These are also contraindicated in uveitis and asthma
  • For eg- Latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost , tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl
  • Latanoprost causes heterochromia iridis
  • Bimatoprost increases both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow
  • Side effects: Hypertrichosis

 

  • Beta-blockers
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: Timolol, betaxolol
    • C/I in asthma
    • S/E: corneal anesthesia and blepharoconjunctivitis

 

  • Alpha agonists:
    • They have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
    • Brimonidine is safe in pregnancy
    • Adrenaline is C/I in aphakic glaucoma

 

  • Miotics:
    • These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage
    • Eg: Pilocarpine
    • S/E of Pilocarpine: Pseudo myopia, retinal detachment, shallow anterior chamber, iris cysts

 

  • Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors:
    • These decrease the formation of aqueous
    • Eg: dorzolamide and brinzolamide
    • These are C/I in sulpha allergies

 

  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: this increases the contractile property of the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing the trabecular outflow and it also decreases the aqueous production.
    • It is a Rho-kinase inhibitor
    • S/E: vortex keratopathy

Systemic:

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • For eg: acetazolamide, methazolamide
    • S/E: Tingling and numbness, constipation, renal stones, and a bad metallic taste
  • Hyperosmotic agents:
    • These draw aqueous out of the eye
    • For eg: I/V mannitol (C/I in heart disease), glycerol (C/I in diabetes), isosorbide, and urea

 

2. Laser :

Laser trabeculoplasty can be done using argon laser (ALT), or Micropulse diode (MLT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT).

3. Surgery:

  • Surgical treatment of POAG primarily consists of a fistulizing (filtration) surgery which provides a new channel for aqueous outflow and successfully controls the IOP .
  • Trabeculectomy is the most frequently performed filtration surgery nowadays.

questions.text: A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text:
Phacolytic glaucoma
B) Malignant glaucoma
C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis
D) Phacomorphic glaucoma

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Glaucoma and the slit lamp image flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens corresponds to secondary open-angle glaucoma called Phacolytic glaucoma.

 

Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Option D)

Phacolytic Glaucoma (Option A)

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork. 

 

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

Malignant glaucoma (Option B) shallowing of the anterior chamber is noticed and Seidel’s test is negative.

Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis (Option C), low-grade flare and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments may be seen but IOP is not very high as in the above case.

questions.text:
Please arrange the following ocular medications according to their respective side effects.


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Amiodarone

			2. Digoxin

			3. Systemic steroids

			4. Hydroxychloroquine
			
			
			A. Retinopathy

			B. Cataract

			C. Yellow vision

			D. Optic neuropathy
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A:

  • It accurately matches the ocular drugs with their corresponding side effects.
    • Amiodarone (1) is associated with optic neuropathy (D).
    • Digoxin (2) is associated with yellow vision (C).
    • Systemic steroids (3) are associated with cataract formation (B).
    • Hydroxychloroquine (4) is associated with retinopathy (A).

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lens induced glaucoma is not incorrect?

choices.text: Phacomorphic glaucoma is an open angle glaucoma
In phacolytic glaucoma lens capsule is intact.
PPhacomorphic glaucoma has a shallow anterior chamber
Mature cataract is an example of phacolytic glaucoma

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phacomorphic glaucoma has a shallow anterior chamber:

  • Phacomorphic glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by a intumescent cataract, anterior subluxation of lens, and spherophakia.
  • In phacomorphic glaucoma, the lens swells, causing a forward displacement of the iris and narrowing or closure of the anterior chamber angle. This leads to increased intraocular pressure.
  • One of the characteristic features of phacomorphic glaucoma is a shallow anterior chamber, which is a consequence of the forward movement of the lens-iris diaphragm.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Phacomorphic glaucoma is an open angle glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma is a type of angle-closure glaucoma.

Option B - In phacolytic glaucoma, the lens capsule is intact: Phacolytic glaucoma occurs due to leakage of lens protein through an intact lens capsule, leading to an inflammatory response and increased intraocular pressure.

Option D - Mature cataract is an example of phacolytic glaucoma: Phacolytic glaucoma is more common in hypermature cataracts where the lens protein leaks through the intact lens capsule, triggering inflammation and increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: What is the name of the device as shown in the image, used for the management of the glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ex-PressTM implant:

  • The Ex-PressTM (mini shunt) implant is a small stainless steel device that is used in glaucoma surgery to facilitate drainage and lower intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • It is implanted under the partial-thickness scleral flap as a modification of trabeculectomy. It provides a more favorable safety and postoperative recovery profile than standard trabeculectomy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ahmed glaucoma valve: It consists of a small tube connected to a plate that is implanted in the eye to facilitate drainage.

Option C - Molteno implant: It involves the placement of a silicone tube with a plate to facilitate drainage.

Option D - Baerveldt implant: It consists of a tube connected to a silicone plate that is implanted in the eye to facilitate drainage.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is 100-day glaucoma observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central retinal vein occlusion:

  • "100-day glaucoma," also known as neovascular glaucoma, can occur as a complication of ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).
  • Ischaemic CRVO (hemorrhagic retinopathy) refers to acute (sudden) complete occlusion of the central retinal vein.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. 100 days glaucoma is not associated with these diseases.

questions.text: A 6-year- old child is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. He has a large port-wine stain on the left side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most ocular manifestation of the underlying condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glaucoma:

  • The clinical presentation of the seizures, port wine stain on face, and leptomeningeal angioma is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
  • The ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome is congenital glaucoma..

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Sturge-Weber syndrome is not associated with these diseases.
